docs.snippet: Trying to burnish their credentials as the champions of underdogs and the scourge of the privileged, Democrats in Congress and around the country are promoting legislation that would prevent American companies from avoiding taxes by reincorporatin...
docs.lead_paragraph: Trying to burnish their credentials as the champions of underdogs and the scourge of the privileged, Democrats in Congress and around the country are promoting legislation that would prevent American companies from avoiding taxes by reincorporating in offshore tax havens. The legislation is driven by public anger over the collapse of the Enron Corporation, which escaped millions of dollars in taxes by creating subsidiaries in countries that are tax havens, and has gained so much momentum that it stands a chance of becoming law this year, despite the opposition of Republican leaders in the House of Representatives and the lack of enthusiasm in the Bush administration.
docs.abstract: Democrats in Congress and around country promote legislation that would prevent American companies from avoiding taxes by reincorporating in offshore tax havens; bill is being driven by public anger over collapse of Enron Corp, which escaped millions of dollars in taxes by creating subsidiaries in countries that are tax havens; it has gained so much momentum that it stands chance of becoming law, despite opposition of Republican leaders in House and lack of enthusiasm in Bush administration; issue is cropping up in congressional races around country (M)

headline.main: Democrats Take Aim at Offshore Tax Havens

docs.snippet: The Swiss bank UBS sought to reassure investors today that it was sticking to its core strategies, despite a switch in top management and plans to acquire the energy-trading operations of the Enron Corporation.     ''The truth is that we are now v...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Swiss bank UBS sought to reassure investors today that it was sticking to its core strategies, despite a switch in top management and plans to acquire the energy-trading operations of the Enron Corporation. ''The truth is that we are now very comfortable with our business and our basic strategy,'' Peter Wuffli, the recently appointed chief, told investors. ''We've shifted to an organization that will primarily grow organically and build on the platform we already have.''
docs.abstract: UBS reassures investors that it is sticking to its core strategies, despite switch in top management and plans to acquire energy-trading operations of Enron Corp (S)

headline.main: UBS Says It Is Sticking to Its Strategy

docs.snippet: Williams Companies, an energy trader and owner of a leading natural gas pipeline network, plans to cut capital spending by $1 billion and sell assets to reassure investors it will not collapse like the Enron Corporation. Proceeds from asset sales ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Williams Companies, an energy trader and owner of a leading natural gas pipeline network, plans to cut capital spending by $1 billion and sell assets to reassure investors it will not collapse like the Enron Corporation. Proceeds from asset sales next year are expected to total $250 million to $750 million, Williams said. The company, based in Tulsa, Okla., also plans to issue $1 billion in convertible preferred stock next year and to reduce 2002 capital spending by 25 percent, to $3 billion. Williams said the moves would help it retain an investment-grade credit rating. Williams' plan includes selling assets like gasoline stations and ethanol production plants, a spokesman, Jim Gipson, said.
docs.abstract: Williams Companies, energy trader and owner of leading natural gas pipeline network, plans to cut capital spending by $1 billion and sell assets to reassure investors it will not collapse like Enron Corp (S)

headline.main: ENERGY COMPANY TAKES STEPS TO INSURE ITS CREDIT RATING

docs.snippet: A day after walking away from a deal to buy the collapsing Enron Corporation, Dynegy is having trouble making a clean break from Enron after all.    With investors nervous, Dynegy's shares fell yesterday, and the company's bond rating is under pre...
docs.lead_paragraph: A day after walking away from a deal to buy the collapsing Enron Corporation, Dynegy is having trouble making a clean break from Enron after all. With investors nervous, Dynegy's shares fell yesterday, and the company's bond rating is under pressure. As a result, Enron's loss may not be Dynegy's gain.
docs.abstract: Dynegy's shares fall and its bond rating is un3

headline.main: Deal Is Over but Not Dynegy's Troubles

docs.snippet: Enron, facing the collapse of a deal with Dynegy that might have rescued it from disaster and a tidal wave of debts suddenly coming due, may now have little choice but to enter bankruptcy, lawyers and analysts said yesterday.    Filing for protect...
docs.lead_paragraph: Enron, facing the collapse of a deal with Dynegy that might have rescued it from disaster and a tidal wave of debts suddenly coming due, may now have little choice but to enter bankruptcy, lawyers and analysts said yesterday. Filing for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code would give the company some much-needed breathing room to deal with creditors' claims, as well as afford any eventual buyer the advantage of a court's approval.
docs.abstract: Enron Corp may have little choice but to enter bankruptcy after collapse of possible deal with Dynegy Inc; some of Enron's most valuable assets are already pledged to lenders, and it is unclear what might be left for holders of its debt and equity and which obligations could be satisfied (M)

headline.main: A Bankruptcy Filing Might Be the Best Remaining Choice

docs.snippet: The Enron Corporation yesterday sliced more than half a billion dollars from its reported profits over the last five years, but its crosstown rival, Dynegy Inc., still appeared to be willing to acquire Enron, executives close to the merger talks s...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation yesterday sliced more than half a billion dollars from its reported profits over the last five years, but its crosstown rival, Dynegy Inc., still appeared to be willing to acquire Enron, executives close to the merger talks said. Worries about how bond rating agencies would react to the merger delayed announcement of the deal, the executives said. But the failure to announce a deal -- as well as the profit restatement -- caused Enron's share price to fall. And volume in its core North American natural gas and electricity trading operation plunged 20 percent as other energy-trading companies, unnerved by Enron's financial distress, steered business elsewhere.
docs.abstract: Enron Corp slices more than half billion dollars from its reported profits over last five years, but its crosstown rival, Dynegy Inc, still appears to be willing to acquire Enron; execs close to merger talks say worries about how bond rating agencies would react to merger delays announcement of deal; photo of Dynegy chief exec Charles L Watson (M)

headline.main: Enron Admits to Overstating Profits by About $600 Million

byline.original: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. and ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

docs.snippet: The Enron Development Corporation received approval today from the Indian Government to proceed with a controversial $2 billion power project in a western state of India.         Clearance by the national Government was the final hurdle for the st...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Development Corporation received approval today from the Indian Government to proceed with a controversial $2 billion power project in a western state of India. Clearance by the national Government was the final hurdle for the stalled project 250 miles south of Bombay. Enron Development, a unit of the Enron Corporation of Houston, revised the project after the Maharashtra state government had canceled it last August.

headline.main: Enron Can Resume Big Indian Power Project

docs.snippet: TO Indians reading about her in the country's newspapers and magazines, Rebecca P. Mark has hardly been presented as a friend of India. Ms. Mark has been widely cast here as a robber baron for her role in winning the Enron Development Corporation,...
docs.lead_paragraph: TO Indians reading about her in the country's newspapers and magazines, Rebecca P. Mark has hardly been presented as a friend of India. Ms. Mark has been widely cast here as a robber baron for her role in winning the Enron Development Corporation, a subsidiary of the Houston-based energy company, a contract to build India's largest-ever power plant. After Enron had spent nearly $300 million, the project was canceled last month by nationalist politicians in Maharashtra state who said India didn't need the plant. So when Ms. Mark left her New Delhi hotel on a recent afternoon to visit the India Gate, a soldiers' memorial that is one of the capital's principal landmarks, it was a surprise to find her surrounded by well-wishers. One man, Rakesh Aggarwal, a New Delhi lawyer sightseeing with his family, put it simply: "Personally, I think India needs power." American Assumptions There is a lesson in this for American companies, and for all outsiders approaching India as it reaches for a new relationship with the world. Many companies responding to India's market-based economic reforms have behaved as if they had read a standard primer on India -- a country that is desperately poor, 60 percent illiterate, but unusual among Asian nations in being a thriving democracy, having English as its common language and a proven legal system. From this, they have assumed a congenial environment for investment.

headline.main: The World; India Repels an Invasion of Money

docs.snippet: The Justice Department asked Congress on Tuesday for a law that would restore powers prosecutors have used against public and private sector officials who intentionally hide conflicts of interest for personal gain....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department asked Congress on Tuesday for a law that would restore powers prosecutors have used against public and private sector officials who intentionally hide conflicts of interest for personal gain, The New York Times's Ashley Southall reported.
docs.abstract: The Justice Department asked Congress on Tuesday for a law that would restore powers prosecutors have used against public and private sector officials who intentionally hide conflicts of interest for personal gain.
